large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: A House in the Sky and Other Uncommon Animal Homes

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to introduce the letters Ww and Xx, engage children with a movement activity, and introduce vocabulary words (cozy, danger).
Begin Story Time by asking: What are some animal homes that animals can live in?
Read for enjoyment and understanding,
Check understanding. Differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe; Use information to categorize.
Identify at least 20 uppercase and 20 lowercase letters in isolation.
Show understanding of text read aloud.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Introduce children to the letters Ww and Xx.
Read aloud We Read and Fox Can Fix It!
Encourage children to identify the sounds /w/ and /eks/.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What is it like where animals live?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What is one animal in that book? Where does that animal live?
What animal will you pretend to be? How will you get home?
Can you name three animal homes?
Can you draw a picture of an animal in its home?
What materials can you use to make an animal home?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word wagon? Can you write it?
Can you use blocks to make an animal home?

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: A House in the Sky and Other Uncommon Animal Homes

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder Identify and Solve Problems and introduce vocabulary (solve, protect).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to A House in the Sky .
Read closely and then talk about how animals solve their problems of finding a home.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe.
Identify at least 20 uppercase and 20 lowercase letters in isolation.
Identify and solve problems.
Show understanding of text read aloud.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children communicate with their peers as they solve an alphabet problem.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What is it like where animals live?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find an animal home in the book?
Can you pretend to be an animal from the book? What would your home be like?
Why do different animals have different homes?
Have you ever solved a problem? Can you write about it?
Can you make your favorite animal home?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word x-ray? Can you write it?
Can you build a tower without letting it fall?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. A House in the Sky and Other Uncommon Animal Homes by Steve Jenkins, illustrated by Robbin Gourley. Text copyright © 2018 by Steve Jenkins. Illustrations copyright © 2018 by Robbin Gourley. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Charlesbridge Publishing, Inc. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: A House in the Sky and Other Uncommon Animal Homes

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background about anial homes, engage children with a song, and introduce the vocabulary (escaping, identify).
Begin Story Time by revisiting A House in the Sky and asking the guiding question: Why are different homes good for different animals?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding, and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe.
Contribute ideas and participate in group writing.
Show understanding of text read aloud.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children identify an animal home in a picture and tell what animals might live there.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What is it like where animals live?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How are some animal homes the same? How are they different?
Can you show me your animal home? Where do you live?
Which is bigger: a nest or a cave?
Write about an animal family in their animal home.
Make an animal house using play clay. What animal home will you create?
Find the letter at the beginning of the word wagon in the Magnetic Letters.
Can you make an animal home for your favorite animal?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. A House in the Sky and Other Uncommon Animal Homes by Steve Jenkins, illustrated by Robbin Gourley. Text copyright © 2018 by Steve Jenkins. Illustrations copyright © 2018 by Robbin Gourley. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Charlesbridge Publishing, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: At the Pond

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about animal homes, engage children with a mime activity, and introduce vocabulary (worms, grasshoppers).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts At the Pond and A House in the Sky .
Read closely to make a connection with the concept question: What is it like where animals live?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe.
Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols.
Show understanding of text read aloud.
Use subject-verb agreement.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.
Use digital learning applications and programs.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Guide children to discuss animals that live at the pond.
Invite children to identify what makes a pond a great home for some animals.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What is it like where animals live?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you make a rhyme with a word you see in your book?
Pretend to be one of the animals that live at the pond. What part of the pond do you live in?
Draw the pond. How many worms can you draw in the dirt?
Pretend you are visiting the pond and see all of these animals. Can you write about your day?
Can you create an animal home we learn about in “At the Pond”? What materials will you use?
Can you write the letter X? Can you draw things that have the letter x in their names?
Can you build an animal home we learn about in “At the Pond”?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. A House in the Sky and Other Uncommon Animal Homes by Steve Jenkins, illustrated by Robbin Gourley. Text copyright © 2018 by Steve Jenkins. Illustrations copyright © 2018 by Robbin Gourley. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Charlesbridge Publishing, Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: A House in the Sky and Other Uncommon Animal Homes

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to actively engage children and introduce vocabulary. (family)
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking: Which animal would you be? Where would you live?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and enjoyment.
Check understanding, and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Share and repeat details in a text.
Write for different purposes.
Identify and verbalize needs.
Show understanding of text read aloud.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the parts of different plants and animals.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: Pretend you live in one of the animal homes in the book. What’s life like in your animal home?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What is it like where animals live?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: If you wrote your own book about an animal home, what would you put in it?
Can you pretend you live in an animal home? How will you tell your parents what you need?
Can you name five animals that live at the pond?
Can you write a story about an animal home?
What materials can you use to make your own home?
Can you find things that start with the /w/ sound?
Can you build the pond where many animals live?

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Name at least 20 uppercase and at least 20 lowercase letters in the language of instruction.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss the characteristics of organisms.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Name at least 20 uppercase and at least 20 lowercase letters in the language of instruction.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss the characteristics of organisms.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Discuss and contribute ideas for drafts composed in whole- /small-group writing activities.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Participate in classroom music activities, including singing, playing musical instruments, and moving to rhythms.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss the characteristics of organisms.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Intentionally use marks, letters, or symbols to record language and verbally share meaning.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Use regular and irregular plurals, regular past tense, personal and possessive pronouns, and subject-verb agreement.
Observe, investigate, describe and discuss the characteristics of organisms.
Open and navigate through digital learning applications and programs.
Retell or re-enact a story after it is read aloud.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Use a large speaking vocabulary, adding several new words daily.
Observes, investigates, describes and discusses the characteristics of organisms.
Create or recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
